function.title: The Function keyword
function.content: This is a JavaScript keyword that declares a function. The whole TC is what they call an IIFE (pronounced 'iffy', but you shouldn't feel that way throughout this journey!)

function-parameters.title: Function Parameters
function-parameters.content:
These are function parameters, values that can be passed to the function.

They can be named anything, it could read (o, r, a, n, g, e) and it would still work as long as the same variable names are changed in the function body

property-access.title: Property access
property-access.content:
An example of accessing the value of a property inside an object. In this case, the property hj is being accessed inside the h variable/object.

In this case, you can see in line 7 of the TC that the first argument passed to the function is window which refers to the global Window object. Since the first parameter of the function is called h we can reference the global window object within the function as h

assignment.title: Assignment (not a homework)
assignment.content:
When you put a value in a variable, it's called Variable Assignment. Here, we're saying that h.hj should be assigned the value h.hj (itself, if it exists).

Whenever you see statements like something = whatever that's an assignment, the trick is the single equals = sign. More than one means something else.

logical-or.title: Logical OR operator
logical-or.content:
When you want to say that something should happen when either of a pair (or more) conditions are true (evaluate to true is the proper term), you can use the Logical OR operator which in JS is simply || (two pipe characters).

Here, OR is saying that if h.hj=h.hj can't happen because that object doesn't exist yet (evaluates to false), then the expression to the right of the || should be assigned to h.hj.

This is useful because if Hotjar already loaded, we don't have to load it again and just assign the current Hotjar global to itself, but if this is the first time we try to load Hotjar, then everything to the right of the OR operator will run.

queue.title: Queueing Hotjar calls
queue.content:
Here we see a similar construct as we just saw, trying to assign a variable to itself if it exists, OR || assigning it the value to the right of the pipes.

In this case, we're looking for the Hotjar q global (or the queue), which is an Array we use to store calls to APIs such as Events and User Attributes while Hotjar hasn't loaded fully so that they may be sent later to Hotjar once it loads.

The [] here means an Array literal that's empty.

push.title: Array.prototype.push()
push.content:
Push is an Array method that pushes a value inside an array as the last index/element in that array, if the array is empty, it would be the first and last element, of course.

Method is a very common term in programming, it means a function that is a property of an object. In JS, almost everything is an object or an instance of an object, including strings, numbers, and in this case, arrays.

arguments.title: The arguments object
arguments.content:
This is where the magic starts happening! At this point, we have a complete and working statement that has some of the barebones functionality that ships with Hotjar.

The arguments object is a collection of all the arguments (values passed in the parenthesis) passed to a function, in this case, the hj function that was just declared.

Try it out yourself, run this line of code window.hj=window.hj||function(){(window.hj.q=window.hj.q||[]).push(arguments)} in your browser Console and then try sending anything using the hj() function, it can be an Event as you might have seen such as hj('event', 'my_wondeful_event') or a flerbo hj('flerbo', 'bleepbloop') or even an emoji hj('ðŸ¥“', 'tasty') Unfortunately, sending bacon to Hotjar, or anything not in our APIs, won't do anything once Hotjar is loaded, the command would just be rejected, but it's a cool way to start understanding how Hotjar works under the hood.
